doc.field: Kaiserslautern German Champion before end of season

The fans of 1. FC Kaiserslautern, the soccer team from the Palatinate, already celebrated their team's victory of the Championship on the next to last day of play. The team of coach Otto Rehagel won against Wolfsburg by 4:0, securing the title. Mr. Rehagel, thanking the players and the fans, said this is an incredible dream coming true. It is unheard of for a team to win the championship title before the end of the season. This is the forth time 1. FC Kaiserslautern holds the title.
First President of European Central Bank designated

Wim Duisenberg of the Netherlands will be the first president of the new European Central Bank. Although the regular term of the president is eight years, Mr. Duisenberg is expected to stay in office for only four years and then to resign, freeing the position for his contender, Mr. Criche of France. This arrangement allowed the French government to achieve a compromise between its own candidate Mr. Criche and the German favorite, Mr. Duisenberg. The heads of state and government continue to debate the assignments for the other positions of the European Central Bank. This morning, the European Parliament voted in favor of enacting the European Monetary Union on January 1, 1999. It will encompass eleven countries. The Parliament thereby has followed the recommendation of the EU Finance Ministers.
Unrest in Berlin after demonstrations on May 1

Following the traditional May 1st rallies, some 6000 participants went on the rampage last night in the Berlin district of Prenzlauer Berg. They hurled cobblestones, bottles and fireworks at the police. The officers responded with tear gas, nightsticks, water canons and armored vehicles. According to a police spokesman, 400 people were taken into custody. Mixed in with the protesters were members of autonomous groups [loosely defined as extreme leftists, translator's note] who, during the day, had been fighting against the demonstrating right-wing extremist NPD in Leipzig.
Mr. Stumpfe considers reduction in unemployment possible

Chairman of the Metal Industry's Trade Association Mr. Stumpfe believes a reduction of unemployment down to 3 or 4 per cent is possible within 10 years. In order for that to occur, the current moderation in wage increases must be continued, Mr. Stumpfe told the news magazine "Focus". It is important that gradual lay-offs not be disrupted at this time. Mr. Stumpfe says "no" to reducing the work week to 32 hours, as proposed by the metal workers' union, IG Metall.
Dialog between SPD and CDU in Saxony-Anhalt

The leadership of the SPD of Saxony-Anhalt convened today to prepare for negotiations with the CDU to form a coalition government. After initial talks, both sides have expressed careful optimism in supporting a "grand coalition" in Saxony-Anhalt.
Porsche and VW to join forces in developing Sport Utility Vehicle

According to the newspaper "Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung", Porsche and VW want to collaborate in developing and building a sport utility vehicle. The supervisory boards of both companies are to decide on the project by June. Porsche has been looking for a partner to design an SUV for some time already. The site of production and assembly of the new vehicle has not be determined yet.
1997: Germans have bought 111 billion DM's worth of cars.

In 1997, Germans bought cars totaling 111 billion marks. This translates to 6 Pfennigs of every mark spent by private households for merchandise and services being allocated for vehicle purchases. According to the Ministry of Economics in Bonn, the same amount was spent on cars as on clothing.
Bertelsmann halts take-over of Random House

The media corporation Bertelsmann has suspended the purchase of the largest U.S. book publisher, Random House, for the time being. According to the New York Times, Bertelsmann has made this move to address concerns of the U.S. Anti-Trust Commission. The latter was poised to subject the take-over to heightened scrutiny, including subpoenaing top managers and confiscating company documents. The German media corporation now wants to eradicate the monopoly concerns first and then refile for the take-over.
